description: A conjunction used to connect two contrasting clauses.
example: このレストランは高いですが、おいしいです。
example_translation: This restaurant is expensive, but it's delicious.

translation: to smell; to feel; to hear
description: Indicates a sensory perception that is noticed by the speaker, often involuntarily.
example: 変な匂いがします。
example_translation: There's a strange smell.

description: Used to embed a yes/no question into a larger sentence to express uncertainty.
example: 彼が来るかどうか分かりません。
example_translation: I don't know whether or not he'll come.

description: A conjunction used to state a reason or cause. The reason precedes から.
example: 疲れましたから、休みます。
example_translation: Because I am tired, I will rest.

description: Changes the state of an object. Use 〜くする for i-adjectives and 〜にする for na-adjectives and nouns.
example: 部屋をきれいにしてください。
example_translation: Please make the room clean.

description: Indicates a change of state. Use 〜くなる for i-adjectives and 〜になる for na-adjectives and nouns.
example: 日本語が上手になりました。
example_translation: My Japanese has become good.

description: Indicates that something happens occasionally. (Verb plain form + ことがある).
example: 時々、朝ご飯を食べないことがあります。
example_translation: Sometimes I don't eat breakfast.

description: A formal way to express ability or possibility. (Verb dictionary form + ことができる).
example: 漢字を読むことができます。
example_translation: I can read kanji.

description: Expresses a decision made by the speaker's own will. (Verb dictionary form + ことにする).
example: 明日からダイエットすることにしました。
example_translation: I decided to start a diet from tomorrow.

description: Indicates a decision made by others or a situation that has been arranged. (Verb dictionary form + ことになる).
example: 来月、大阪へ出張することになりました。
example_translation: It has been decided that I will go on a business trip to Osaka next month.

description: Used to list multiple reasons or characteristics
example: often to support a conclusion.
example_translation: このアパートは駅に近いし、家賃も安いし、とてもいいです。
category: This apartment is close to the station, and the rent is cheap, so it's very good.

description: Indicates excess. Attaches to the verb stem (e.g., 食べすぎる) or adjective stem (e.g., 高すぎる).
example: 食べすぎました。
example_translation: I ate too much.

description: Expresses a judgment based on visual evidence. Attaches to the verb stem (e.g.
example: 降りそう) or adjective stem (e.g.
example_translation: 美味しそう).
level: It looks like it will rain.

description: Used to convey information heard from another source. Attaches to the plain form of verbs
example: nouns
example_translation: and adjectives.
category: 天気予報によると、明日は晴れるそうです。
column9: I heard it will be sunny tomorrow.

description: Used to describe the apparent desire or wish of a third person. (Verb stem + たがる).
example: 息子は新しいゲームをたがっています。
example_translation: My son wants a new game.

description: Indicates limitation or extent.
example: 好きなだけ食べてください。
example_translation: Please eat as much as you like.

description: A strong way to express limitation
example: always used with a negative verb ending.
example_translation: 日本語だけしか話せません。

description: Used to add another piece of information.
example: 彼は日本語だけでなく、英語も話せます。
example_translation: He can speak not only Japanese but also English.

description: Expresses past experience. (Verb ta-form + ことがある).
example: 日本に行ったことがあります。
example_translation: I have been to Japan before.

translation: in order to; for the purpose of
description: Expresses purpose or reason. (Verb dictionary form / Noun の + ために).
example: 日本語を勉強するために、日本へ行きます。
example_translation: I will go to Japan in order to study Japanese.

description: A conditional form used for a wide range of situations
example: including hypotheticals. The action in the たら clause must complete first.
example_translation: 雨が降ったら、出かけません。
category: If it rains, I won't go out.

translation: do things like A and B
description: Used to list example actions without being exhaustive. (Verb ta-form + り).
example: 週末は映画を見たり、本を読んだりします。
example_translation: On weekends, I do things like watch movies and read books.

description: Plain form of でしょう, used to express conjecture or probability.
example: 彼は来ないだろう。
example_translation: He probably won't come.

translation: I intend to; I plan to
description: Expresses a firm intention or plan. (Verb dictionary form + つもりです).
example: 大学院へ行くつもりです。
example_translation: I intend to go to graduate school.

description: To do a favor for someone else (of equal or lower status).
example: 母にプレゼントを買ってあげました。
example_translation: I bought a present for my mom.

description: Indicates a state that exists as the result of a deliberate
example: preparatory action.
example_translation: 窓が開けてあります。
category: The window has been left open (intentionally).

translation: to go on doing; to continue
description: Indicates an action that will continue from the present into the future.
example: 日本語の勉強を続けていきます。
example_translation: I will continue studying Japanese.

translation: be doing; in a state of
description: Indicates a progressive action or a continuous state.
example: 彼は今テレビを見ています。
example_translation: He is watching TV now.

description: To do something beforehand in preparation for the future.
example: 友達が来るので、掃除しておきます。
example_translation: Since my friend is coming, I'll clean up in advance.

translation: to come to; to start to
description: Indicates an action that began in the past and continues to the present
example: or movement towards the speaker.
example_translation: 雨が降ってきました。

description: Indicates that someone does a favor for the speaker or someone in their in-group.
example: 友達が手伝ってくれました。
example_translation: My friend helped me.

translation: to do completely; to do accidentally
description: Expresses the completion of an action
example: or that an action was done accidentally or with regret.
example_translation: 宿題を忘れてしまいました。
category: I completely forgot my homework (with regret).

description: Polite form used to express conjecture or to seek confirmation.
example: 明日は雨が降るでしょう。
example_translation: It will probably rain tomorrow.

description: Used to prohibit an action.
example: ここで写真を撮ってはいけません。
example_translation: You must not take pictures here.

description: To try doing something to see what it's like.
example: 日本料理を食べてみたいです。
example_translation: I want to try eating Japanese food.

description: Indicates a concession or a hypothetical contrary condition.
example: 雨が降っても、行きます。
example_translation: I will go even if it rains.

description: Used to give or ask for permission.
example: 電話を使ってもいいですか。
example_translation: May I use the phone?

description: A way to grant permission
example: implying it will not be a bother.
example_translation: 窓を開けてもかまいません。
category: I don't mind if you open the window.

translation: to get someone to do something
description: To receive a favor from someone else.
example: 先生に説明してもらいました。
example_translation: I had the teacher explain it to me.

description: Expresses that an action is futile or pointless.
example: 後悔しても始まりません。
example_translation: There's no use regretting it.

description: Expresses relief or happiness about something that happened.
example: 傘を持ってきてよかったです。
example_translation: I'm glad I brought an umbrella.

description: Expresses the speaker's desire for someone else to perform an action.
example: 手伝ってほしいです。
example_translation: I want you to help me.

description: A conditional used for natural
example: inevitable
example_translation: or habitual results.
category: 春になると、花が咲きます。

description: Indicates the time when something happens.
example: 子供のとき、ここに住んでいました。
example_translation: When I was a child, I lived here.

translation: about to; in the middle of; just did
description: Expresses the immediate stage of an action (before
example: during
example_translation: or after).
category: 今から食べるところです。
level: I'm just about to eat now.

description: Used to express the speaker's opinion or thoughts.
example: 彼は来ないと思います。
example_translation: I think he won't come.

description: Indicates that two actions are performed simultaneously by the same person. (Verb stem + ながら).
example: 音楽を聞きながら、勉強します。
example_translation: I study while listening to music.

description: Expresses obligation or necessity. Interchangeable with なければいけない / ならない.
example: 勉強しなくてはいけません。
example_translation: I must study.

description: A slightly more formal way to express obligation or necessity.
example: 明日までに終わらなくてはなりません。
example_translation: It must be finished by tomorrow.

description: Expresses a lack of obligation or necessity.
example: 明日は学校に行かなくてもいいです。
example_translation: You don't have to go to school tomorrow.

description: Expresses obligation or necessity.
example: 薬を飲まなければいけません。
example_translation: I have to take my medicine.

description: Expresses strong obligation or necessity.
example: もっと勉強しなければなりません。
example_translation: I have to study more.

description: A conditional used to give a suggestion or limitation based on what the other person said.
example: あなたが行くなら、私も一緒に行きます。
example_translation: If you are going (since we are on that topic), I will go with you too.

description: Attached to a verb stem to indicate that an action is difficult to perform.
example: この靴は歩きにくいです。
example_translation: These shoes are hard to walk in.

description: Used to express a choice made at the time of speaking.
example: コーヒーにします。
example_translation: I'll have the coffee.

description: Indicates a natural change or transformation.
example: 先生になります。
example_translation: I will become a teacher.

description: A conjunction used to state a reason or cause. Softer and more polite than から.
example: 安いので、買いました。
example_translation: Since it was cheap, I bought it.

description: Used to connect two clauses
example: where the second is an unexpected or contrary result.
example_translation: 雨が降っているのに、出かけます。
category: Even though it's raining, I will go out.

description: A conditional form
example: often used for general truths or hypothetical situations.
example_translation: 安ければ、買います。
category: If it's cheap, I'll buy it.

description: Indicates that as one thing increases
example: another thing increases proportionally.
example_translation: 練習すればするほど、上手になります。
category: The more you practice, the better you get.

description: Indicates that someone does only one thing
example: or that only one type of thing exists. Often has a negative nuance.
example_translation: 甘い物ばかり食べています。

translation: to keep on; to continue to
description: Expresses a continuing trend
example: often a negative one.
example_translation: 物価が上がるばかりです。

description: Indicates that a single cause led to an unfortunate result.
example: 病気だったばかりに、試験を受けられませんでした。
example_translation: Simply because I was sick, I couldn't take the exam.

translation: had better; it is better to
description: Used to give advice. (Verb ta-form for positive advice
example: Verb nai-form for negative advice).
example_translation: 薬を飲んだほうがいいですよ。
category: You had better take some medicine.

description: An informal way to express resemblance or make a guess.
example: 彼は学生みたいです。
example_translation: He seems like a student.

description: Used to list non-exhaustive examples.
example: 机の上に本やノートなどがあります。
example_translation: There are things like books and notebooks on the desk.

description: Attached to a verb stem to indicate that an action is easy to perform.
example: このペンは書きやすいです。
example_translation: This pen is easy to write with.

description: Used to express intention (volitional form) or make a suggestion. よう is the plain form
example: ましょう is the polite form.
example_translation: 食べよう。/ 食べましょう。

description: Indicates that there is no means or way to perform an action. (Verb stem + ようがない).
example: そんなことは知りようがありません。
example_translation: There's no way I could know that.

description: Expresses a conjecture based on sensory evidence or information. More formal than みたい.
example: 彼は疲れているようです。
example_translation: He seems tired.

translation: to try to; to be about to
description: Expresses an attempt to do something.
example: 寝ようとしましたが、眠れませんでした。
example_translation: I tried to sleep but couldn't.

translation: I think I'll...; am planning to
description: Expresses an intention or plan formed by the speaker. (Volitional form + と思う).
example: 来年、日本へ留学しようと思います。
example_translation: I'm thinking of studying abroad in Japan next year.

description: Indicates a conscious effort to make something a habit.
example: 毎日運動するようにしています。
example_translation: I make an effort to exercise every day.

description: Indicates a function or system that is in place
example: often automatically.
example_translation: このドアは自動で閉まるようになっています。
category: This door is designed to close automatically.

translation: to come to be able to; to reach the point where
description: Expresses a change in ability or state over time.
example: 日本語が話せるようになりました。
example_translation: I've reached the point where I can speak Japanese.

translation: it seems; I hear; typical of
description: Expresses a judgment based on hearsay or evidence. Can also mean something is typical of a category.
example: 彼は先生らしいです。
example_translation: I hear he is a teacher. / He acts like a teacher.

description: Indicates a strong reason or condition for an obligation. (Plain form + 以上).
example: 約束した以上、守らなければなりません。
example_translation: Now that you've promised, you must keep it.

translation: less than or equal to; below
description: Expresses a limit and everything at or below it.
example: 10歳以下の子供は無料です。
example_translation: Children 10 years old and under are free of charge.

description: Indicates exclusion from a group or condition.
example: 彼以外は全員来ました。
example_translation: Everyone except for him came.

description: Indicates the start of an action. (Verb stem + 始める).
example: 彼は走り始めました。
example_translation: He started to run.

description: Indicates the method of doing something. (Verb stem + 方).
example: この漢字の書き方を教えてください。
example_translation: Please teach me how to write this kanji.

description: Indicates desire for a tangible or intangible object.
example: 新しい車が欲しいです。
example_translation: I want a new car.

description: A suffix that turns a noun into a na-adjective.
example: 科学的な証明
example_translation: a scientific proof

description: Indicates the completion of an action. (Verb stem + 終わる).
example: 宿題をやり終わりました。
example_translation: I finished doing my homework.

description: Indicates that a specific event occurs within the time frame of another ongoing action.
example: 勉強している間に、雨が降りました。
example_translation: It rained while I was studying.

description: Used to compare something to a noun
example: like an adjective.
example_translation: 彼女は天使のような人です。
category: She is a person like an angel.

description: Used to describe an action that is done in a similar way to something else.
example: 鳥のように飛べたらいいのに。
example_translation: I wish I could fly like a bird.

description: Expresses a possibility. More polite than かもしれない.
example: 明日は雨が降るかもしれません。
example_translation: It might rain tomorrow.

description: Emphasizes a small quantity or a specific action
example: always used with a negative verb.
example_translation: 百円しかありません。

description: Indicates a sequence of actions; B happens after A is completed.
example: 宿題をしてから、テレビを見ます。
example_translation: I will watch TV after doing my homework.

description: A command form used by superiors to inferiors (e.g.
example: parents to children). Softer than the imperative form. (Verb stem + なさい).
example_translation: 早く寝なさい。

description: Used to provide an explanation
example: add emphasis
example_translation: or ask for clarification. The plain form is のだ.
category: どうして遅れたんですか。
level: Why is it that you were late?

description: Indicates the sudden start of an action. (Verb stem + 出す).
example: 赤ちゃんが急に泣き出しました。
example_translation: The baby suddenly started to cry.

description: Indicates that one action takes place before another. (Verb dictionary form / Noun の + 前に).
example: 寝る前に、本を読みます。
example_translation: I read a book before sleeping.

description: Indicates that one action takes place after another. (Verb ta-form / Noun の + 後で).
example: ご飯を食べた後で、散歩します。
example_translation: I will take a walk after eating.

description: Indicates the continuation of an action. (Verb stem + 続ける).
example: 彼は走り続けました。
example_translation: He continued to run.

description: The humble form of します
example: used when talking about your own actions to someone of higher status.
example_translation: 私がご案内いたします。

translation: to be; to come; to go (respectful)
description: Respectful form (sonkeigo) of いる
example: 来る
example_translation: and 行く.
category: 先生はいらっしゃいますか。

description: A casual, typically male, sentence-ending particle for yes/no questions.
example: 行くかい。
example_translation: Are you going?

description: Indicates the raw material something is made from, where the original material is not obvious.
example: 木から紙を作ります。
example_translation: Paper is made from wood.

translation: to show signs of; to feel (third person)
description: Used to describe the apparent feelings or desires of a third person.
example: 彼は犬を怖がっています。
example_translation: He is scared of dogs.

description: Indicates that something is necessary.
example: お金が必要です。
example_translation: Money is necessary.

description: An adverb used to express a high degree of certainty.
example: 彼はきっと来ます。
example_translation: He will surely come.

description: The polite form of あります.
example: ここにございます。
example_translation: It is here.

description: A suffix that turns a verb or verb phrase into a noun.
example: 食べることが好きです。
example_translation: I like eating.

description: A casual
example: masculine way to seek confirmation or express a strong opinion.
example_translation: いいじゃないか。

description: Indicates that an outcome is achieved simply by performing a certain action.
example: 英語を勉強するだけで、上達します。
example_translation: You can improve just by studying English.

description: Marks the location where an action takes place.
example: 図書館で勉強します。
example_translation: I study at the library.

description: Marks the means
example: tool
example_translation: or method used to perform an action.

description: A very polite and formal form of です.
example: こちらでございます。
example_translation: This is it.

description: A formal way to seek confirmation or agreement.
example: きれいではないか。
example_translation: Isn't it pretty?

description: Used to make a casual suggestion.
example: コーヒーでも飲みましょうか。
example_translation: Shall we have coffee or something?

description: Marks a specific point in time (e.g.
example: 7時
example_translation: 月曜日).

description: Marks the destination or goal of movement verbs.
example: 日本に行きます。
example_translation: I will go to Japan.

translation: it is expected that; should be
description: Expresses a strong conviction or logical assumption that something is true or will happen.
example: 彼は今日、来るはずです。
example_translation: He is supposed to come today.

description: Used to express strong disbelief or that something is impossible.
example: そんなはずがありません。
example_translation: That can't possibly be true.

description: Expresses that an expected action has not happened yet.
example: まだ昼ご飯を食べていません。
example_translation: I haven't eaten lunch yet.

description: Used to add emphasis to a hypothetical conditional situation.
example: もしお金があったら、旅行します。
example_translation: If I had money, I would travel.

translation: in the case of; in the event that
description: Used to indicate a specific case or situation.
example: 病気の場合は、連絡してください。
example_translation: In case of sickness, please contact me.

description: Used to express necessity. More formal than なければいけない.
example: 勉強する必要があります。
example_translation: It is necessary to study.

description: An adverb indicating a sudden action or change.
example: 急に雨が降りました。
example_translation: It suddenly started to rain.

description: Indicates a period during which a state or action continues.
example: 彼が寝ている間、私はテレビを見ていました。
example_translation: I was watching TV while he was sleeping.

description: Used to indicate an approximate point in time.
example: 3時頃に行きます。
example_translation: I will go around 3 o'clock.
